Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Preston D. Wake is "Algebraic Number Theory." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California-Los Angeles, and the sponsoring scientist is Haruzo Hida.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Preston Wake completed his postdoctoral training as a NSF Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellow. During his funding period, he spent two academic years at the University of California Los Angeles working with the sponsoring scientist Professor Haruzo Hida. The title of the project was "algebraic number theory", focusing on applying techniques of Galois deformation theory to problems in Iwasawa theory, especially Sharifi's conjectures. This is an area of mathematics that provides the foundations of public key cryptography by providing a source of problems that are easy to understand but remarkably difficult to compute.

 

This fellowship was very successful in developing Dr Wake into a professional mathematician. During his fellowship, he was invited to present his research 19 times, and published five papers in prominent journals. This led to his receiving a prestigious one-year membership at the Institute for Advanced Study followed by a tenure-track position at Michigan State University.
The fellowship also afforded Dr Wake the opportunity to positively impact the mathematical community more broadly. He organized three separate expository seminars at UCLA, aimed at helping graduate students and postdocs learn cutting edge techniques. He also served as project assistant at the Arizona Winter School, a major conference for graduate students in number theory. There, he mentored twelve graduate students in three research projects, giving the students the opportunity to work on research outside their thesis area. One of these projects led to a joint paper between Dr Wake, three of the students, and another mentor.
